description: Multiyear partnerships simplify grantmaking, reduce the time spent on scouting new grantees and projects, and help funders gain a deeper understanding of social issues. Engaging in these longer-term partnerships allows funders to move from being only grant makers to playing the role of advisors to nonprofit partners and can facilitate greater job enrichment for program teams as they are able to invest more time and effort in understanding nonprofit needs and support them in delivering on their intended impact. Multiyear partnerships nurture trust as relationships between funders and nonprofits deepen over time and a mutual understanding of a nonprofit’s needs and goals grows. For funders, adopting a multiyear approach can help increasingly focus on creating lasting change, over immediate and short-term outputs. Additionally, it enables stability and visibility for nonprofits to plan and direct efforts on their core focus.
name: pm84tbr7tr

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Revisiting your policy in context of your impact goals and ascertain any biases or blind spots that might be limiting multiyear partnerships (such as extending multiyear funding only to large nonprofits with a credible funder baser rather than small, community-based nonprofits).


  1. If alignment on policy is a barrier, engage with senior leadership and board / committee on the need, benefits and alignment with the Foundation/ CSRs vision and goals, to increase the number of multiyear partnerships. Lay out the opportunity cost (e.g., costs associated with sourcing and diligence). Leverage research and evidence, and showcase examples from funders/ NGOs who have fostered multiyear partnerships.
recommended_actions.title: Policy guidelines

recommended_actions.actions:
1. Evaluating your current funding portfolio to understand the percentage of funding allocated to multiyear partnerships and the number of nonprofits being supported in this regard. If the percentage is low, reflect on internal awareness and mindsets that may be influencing current practices.


  1. Encourage program officers to look at current grantee partners to assess where a long-term partnership might be most fruitful


  1. Engage with existing and potential nonprofits on their 3–5-year strategy and impact goals, and how your funding can enable your collective mission. Customize grants to best suit their needs (both current and future) and objectives.
recommended_actions.title: Annual budget allocation

recommended_actions.actions:
• Having a clearly defined, realistic criteria (e.g., mission alignment, demonstrated impact, etc.) for nonprofit selection that allows for uniform and consistent decision making, and ensure shared understanding and transparency amongst internal stakeholders and nonprofit partners. Assess if criteria might be too stringent and unrealistic for nonprofits to fulfill and have internal conversation to ascertain if these criteria need to be modified.


  • Engage with eligible or near eligible nonprofits to understand the barriers they perceive in seeking multiyear partnerships to further your understanding.
recommended_actions.title: Approaches adopted

recommended_actions.actions:
• Establishing a clear strategy and avenues for communication both internally within the organization and with nonprofits and the sector. Share your willingness to enter into multiyear partnerships and what would make a nonprofit eligible for consideration both in partner meetings, group convenings and in the wider sector.


  • Actively and continuously engage with nonprofit partners and internally to understand the challenges, gaps, opportunities on this aspect, going beyond structured reporting to also include informal conversations, immersive field visits, etc. to better understand your nonprofit partner’s evolving context and needs.
recommended_actions.title: Channels of communication

description: Organisational development (OD) investments build and strengthen a range of critical efficiency and growth-oriented capabilities, such as in strategic planning, leadership and talent development, and financial management, that enable nonprofits to deliver greater impact. Funders that invest in OD help to unlock their nonprofit partners’ impact potential. Research has shown when nonprofits invest in OD, they double their programme output over a three-to-five-year period and became more financially secure. Here’s where your organization ranks on several dimensions of organisational development.
name: vltmcn5a4c

recommended_actions.actions:
• Speaking to peers who have funded their nonprofit partners’ OD and seek their advice on how to proceed. Leverage learnings from initiatives.

﻿

  • Leverage case studies of how nonprofits have benefited from OD investments, and how funders have achieved greater impact after investing in grantees’ organisational needs, such as Ford Foundation’s Building Institutions and Networks (BUILD) initiative, Oak Foundation and five other European Foundation’s OD investments, EdelGive Foundation’s GROW Fund, and domestic and CSR funders practices on investing in OD, to drive internal consensus.


  • Engage with OD champions within your organisation to build a compelling case for OD funding.
recommended_actions.title: Policy guidelines

recommended_actions.actions:
• Taking steps to increase OD budgetary allocation in the annual planning cycle. One can start with seeking feedback on the duration and quantum of funding which can help nonprofit partners invest in their OD needs better, assess the gap between current allocation and requirements, and leverage this to pitch for internal budgetary allocations.

﻿

  • In case utilization of budget is a constraint, consider adding OD funding to the organisations that receive multiyear support along with program funding.
recommended_actions.title: Annual budget allocation

recommended_actions.actions:
• Training your programme managers to engage with nonprofits to better understand their individualised OD needs.


  • In case your nonprofit partners are new to OD, connect them with information, toolkits, and peer organisations to help them learn how to determine their OD needs.


  • As you extend OD funding to nonprofits, engage them to understand the outcomes of such funding in the short term and and longer term, and identify areas where you can further strengthen your practices.


  • Document learnings to share with internal and external stakeholders to showcase the impact of supporting OD.

﻿

  • Incase you want to test out the approach, identify collaborative/pooled funds that provide OD support to nonprofits to learn how those investments fared. Learning from piloting OD investments by allocating a percentage of your total funding towards OD grants.
recommended_actions.title: Approaches adopted

recommended_actions.actions:
• Establishing formal channels for communication within the organization, with nonprofits, and the sector. Share your guidelines for OD with nonprofit partners, group convenings, and in the sector.


  • Provide training to your grant staff and programme officers to understand the importance of investing in nonprofits’ OD and actively engaging with them to understand their needs based on their impact goals, stage of growth, and programmatic priorities.


  • If you have chosen to support only specific OD capabilities, clearly communicate these priorities to your nonprofit partners, along with the rationale for the choices. Communicate flexibility that you may be able to exercise, and the criteria for such decisions.

﻿

  • Create spaces for seeking feedback from internal teams and nonprofit partners to understand the challenges, gaps, opportunities for providing support on OD.
recommended_actions.title: Channels of communication

description: Financial resilience refers to a nonprofit’s ability to sustain its operations long term and withstand external stresses and shocks, such as the COVID-19 pandemic or the end of a key funder’s support. Nonprofits pursue financial resilience by developing prudent financial plans, monitoring financial performance, diversifying their funder base, and building reserve funds. Funders help by contributing to nonprofit reserves and introducing nonprofits to like-minded funders. Here’s where you organization ranks on several dimensions of financial resilience.
name: ektop2co82

recommended_actions.actions:
• Revisiting your policy in the context of your impact goals to assess your ability and staff interest in supporting nonprofit financial resilience.

﻿

  • Engaging with your nonprofit partners to better understand their needs and plan for building reserves.
recommended_actions.title: Policy guidelines

recommended_actions.actions:
• Introducing nonprofits in your portfolio to other funders to help them diversify their funder base.

﻿

  • Supporting nonprofit partners directly or through a financial intermediary to develop a multiyear financial plan that analyses how best to allocate available funding.


  • Exploring providing financial support to nonprofit parnters, and actively engage with them to understand the outcomes of such funding in the immediate and longer-term.
recommended_actions.title: Approaches adopted

recommended_actions.actions:
• Establishing formal channels for communication within the organization, with nonprofits, and the sector. Share your guidelines for financial resilience support – both financial and non-financial – extended with nonprofit partners, group convenings, and in the sector.


  • If you have chosen to provide only non-financial support, clearly communicate these priorities to your nonprofit partners, along with the rationale for this choice. Communicate flexibility that you may be able to exercise, and the criteria for such decisions.

﻿

  • Create spaces for seeking feedback from internal teams and nonprofit partners to understand the challenges, gaps, opportunities for providing financial and non-financial support to build nonprofts’ resilience.
recommended_actions.title: Channels of communication

description: Core costs, often called indirect costs, involve administrative or support-function expenses not tied to a specific programme, such as salaries of nonprogramme employees, rent and utilities for a central office, fundraising, and measurement and evaluation. Funders that pay a fair share of core costs ensure that a nonprofit is able to conduct its day-to-day operations and deliver on its impact mandates. Here’s where your organisation ranks on several dimensions of core costs.
name: k8gmpe4f02

recommended_actions.actions: • Revisiting your guidelines to take into account the full range of costs a nonprofit incurs to do its work. Do not rely on a low, fixed core-cost rate as standard practice. Bridgespan’s analysis of 40 well-funded Indian nonprofits revealed that actual indirect core costs can range from 5 percent to 51 percent, averaging 19 percent. Leading global funders like Ford Foundation, MacArthur Foundation, and The David & Lucile Packard Foundation have overtime, and in georgraphies where it is legally permissible, either created thresholds greater than 20%, or have completely moved away from having an upper limit on the core cost that they cover.
recommended_actions.title: Policy guidelines

recommended_actions.actions:
• Undertake an assessment of your current core-cost limit against the needs of your nonprofit partner’s actual core-cost needs, and identify whether there is a gap in the support you are extending.


  • Incorporate a consultative process during the proposal and grant renewal stages to better understand a nonprofit’s core cost needs, and discuss how these costs can enable the organisation to deliver the desired programmatic impact.


  • Communicate the flexibility that you will extend to nonprofits and your expectations of them, such as a well-structured budget and clear justification of costs.

﻿

  • As needed, connect your nonprofit partners with third parties professionals to help them compute their core costs. Based on the computation, pay your fair share as a proportion of the nonprofits’s total funding.
recommended_actions.title: Approaches adopted

recommended_actions.actions:
• Establish formal channels for communication within the organization, with nonprofits, and the sector. Share your guidelines for multiyear partnerships with nonprofit partners, group convenings, and in the sector.


  • Share the process that you use to establish core-cost support with nonprofit partners to ensure transparency through the grantmaking process.

﻿

  • Create spaces for seeking feedback from internal teams and nonprofit partners to to reflect on and enhance your core cost policy.
recommended_actions.title: Channels of communication
